176 To the Secretary of the State Board of Irrigation Biennial report of H. 0. Smith, Under Secretary for Water Divi* ion No. 1. t There has been a very marked improvement in the conditions re - ig to irrigation in Western Nebraska during the bi-ennium of 1907 iver those existing in the prior years, especially the earlier periods 900 to 1904. It is probably true that this improvement is partly to an increased rainfall in that territory, though the records do no >r a very material increase for a period of years and practically none the years 190 7 and 1908. There are other causes that have con utecl more to this improvement than the slightly increased rainfall In the smaller streams, and it is in the valleys of these stream that a large proportion of the irrigated lands of the State are located there is a very noticeable increase in the normal flow and in the regu larity of the flow. I attribute this to two principal causes; First — the more water there is used, and the longer it is used, the greater is the seepage ba< k into the parent stream, in fact the water applied to the land is not lost but stored and gradually and steadily though slowly re turns to the stream, resulting in a great improvement in the regularit. of the flow. Cultivation of the land is also an important factor in this storage problem. Second — Under the policies and rules of the irriga tion department the excessive and wasteful methods of irrigation prac tired in the early days have been succeeded by economical and intelli gent methods, to the great advantage of the individual irrigator am benefit of the irrigators on the stream collectively. There is still room for improvement on these lines. Lodge Pole Creek is a typical stream for this state and one on which the methods of using water have been probably, more effectively reformed than any other stream in state, a least I have no knoweldge of any other where the conditions have been so much improved. The records show that on no other stream in the state is there as great an erea of land irrigated in proportion to the volume of the flow as on this stream. The amount of water appropriated from Lodge Pole Creek in Nebraska is 139.87 second feet, covering 9790 acres. The flow of the stream during the irrigation season amounts to from 4 to 20 second feet exclusive of floods, of which nothing is utilized because of lack of storage facilities. I As an example of the improvement effected, on the Bennett ranch be eastern part of Kimball County, which includes about six miles ,odge Pole valley, prior to 1904 were two small ditches covering a 1 of about 400 acres, but owing to the irregularity and a scarcity rater supply at that point, in no season was more than half o land irrigated. In 1904 a new system of ditches was commence: completed in 1905. Under the improved conditions more than 240ft s of land on this ranch were successfully and effectively irrigated ng each of the years 1907 and 1908.

177 there is an enormous loss of valuable water in the winter flow which is considerably greater than the summer flow, and in the heavy floods which frequently sweep down the valley, leaving a trail o wrecked bridges, dams and ditches. There is a move on foot in Kim ball County to conserve and store this flow and it is to be hoped that i will be successfully carried out. Such a waste of so valuable an ad junct to production is repulsive to the American idea of thrift and i not to be tolerated. It is a pity that in this matter Nebraska should be so far behind her neighboring states. In" Colorado and Wyoming mi mense sums of money have been invested, not spent, in storing ever available foot of water, and not without adequate returns. Six to eight years ago non-irrigable lands in Western Nebraska were valued at $ 1 per acre and no market. Today they find ready sale at $7 per acre. At the same time irrigated lands were valued at from $10 to $20 per acre, today they sell for $100 per acre and up. tSome day the people of Nebraska will awake to the fact that it valuable possessions are located in the western part, the part tha present thought but little of, and spoken of but slightingly. Bu s, outsiders with experience with similar conditions in other states e these valuable resources are utilized, will get on the groun reap the benefits. Respectfully submitted. H. O. 180 The Wyoming law, which provides for a primary permit covering the construction of a reservoir and a secondary permit indicating the lands upcn which the water is to be used, seems to be a good provision Under our law, the applicant for a permit to appropriate water mus in his application describe fully the lands which he intends to irrigate and within six months after the allowance of the application for a per mit. a map must be filed on a scale of not less than two inches to the mile, showing the location and the course of the distributing works the source from which the appropriation is taken, and the lega sub-divisions of the land upon which the water appropriated is to be applied. This section should be amended so as to provide that thes maps should be made in a uniform manner, in accordance with th rules laid down by the Secretary of the State Board of Irrigation, and that all such maps should have a certificate made by some competen engineer or surveyor certifying to the accuracy of the same. KAs the matter now stands, the applicant generally attempts to e his own maps, and in the majority of cases, these maps are in - rate and do not give sufficient data upon which to base the issuance certificate of appropriation. Our law seems to provide that the water appropriated is attached to the la'nd for which the permit is granted, and that no change may be made in the place of use. There are many cases where it would seem only just that the right to change the place of use should be permittee and I believe it would be well to adopt a provision similar to the one in force in some of the states, which provides that if for any reason i should at any time become impracticable to use all or any part of the water to which the right of use is appurtenant, part or all of the righ may be severed from this land and simultaneously transferred and be - come appurtenant to other lands without losing priority of right, where the change can be made without detriment to existing rights. All such changes, however, should be made only upon permits issue! by the State Engineer, after a careful examination of the conditions and the rights of others diverting water from the stream. DISTIUIT 1KKIGATIOX LAW. iir district irrigation law, which was copied largely from the Wright of California, is designed to enable users of water to own and con the irrigation works supplying their lands, and provides for the ion of the Board of Directors who have the power to construct am ate canals and to issue bends for the payment of all construction c and to levy an annual tax for the payment of operating expenses to pay interest on the bonds and form a sinking funi for the fina oent of the bonds themselves. The district irrigation law provides a very satisfactory method for the development of the district, anl in most cases the formation o these districts has proven quite satisfactory. Bach lani owner being directly interested in the conduct of tbe affairs of the district, al parties are inclinej to wcrk together for the best interests of the district.

181 There are a number of amendments, however, which I believe should be made to this law. At present, whenever a majority of the electors holding land in any district subject to one mode of irrigation desire to do so, they may propose the organization of an irrigation district, and must file with the Board of County Commissioners a peti - tion signed by the majority of these directors. This petition must sho» the boundaries of the proposed district. 1 believe that after this peti - tion is filed with the Board of County Commissioners, a copy should be filed with the Secretary of the State Board of Irrigation for the pur - pose of determining whether the lands included within the3e boundaries are susceptible of irrigation from the proposed works, whether or uot any of them are covered by prior appropriations, and also to report upon the adequacy of the water supply before any further steps are taken toward the organization of the district. Our law provides that Board of Directors of any district must as soon after such district has been organized as may be practicable, estab - lish and determine the amount of money to be raised, and shall immedi ately call an election to vote upon a bond proposition. 1 believe tha before this question of voting bonds is submitted to the electors, an nate of the probable cost of construction should be made by a com petent engineer, and filed with the Board of Directors. After the bond., have been voted, the law should require that complete plans and speci fications with an estimate of cost be made by a competent engineer and filed with the Board of Directors. A copy of these plans and speci flcations should be referred to the State Board of Irrigation for its ap - proval. In this way. many costly mistakes might be preventeJ. tl believe also that the bonds of an irrigation district should be itered with the State Auditor, so that all matters pertaining to regularity of their issuance, might be passed upon. This would the bonds a much better standing than they have under the ent law. Every district organized under the provisions of this law, should be required to file in the office of the State Board of Irrigation a complete record of all matters pertaining to its organization issuance of bonds, etc., and the officers of the district should niak annual reports to the State Board of Irrigation showing concisely the management of the affairs of the district, the amount of tax levied and a list of the district officers. Under the present law many districts are organized of which this office has no knowledg whatever, and while we have attempted to keep a complete list o districts organized, it has been quite impossible to keep up such list with any degree of accuracy, and this office has no officia record of the boundaries of an irrigation district, the amount o bonds issued, or anything pertaining to district organization. Man inquiries are made to this office in regard to these districts, an I believe that a complete record should be on file. fOOl'EKATIOX WITH V. S. GOVERNMENT. 184 became dry it was again disked and 4 >* acres planted to sugar beets, by Anton Kokenis, to whom that part of the field was leased. When the ground was flooded it was observed that the imper vious character of the soil prevented the ready percolation of the water into the drains, especially where there were surface depressions The soil under wet conditions appears black and waxy in these place and the continued saturation to which the soil was subjected, did not better its condition but rather made it worse. Notwithstanding these conditions, a considerable flow of water passed out of the drains, its color indicating that it was highly charged with alkali A part of the water was removed by the few surface ditches whirl were provided, apparently producing a better and more immediate result than where the water was retained on the soil and permitte to pass off through the under drains only. The beets were not planted until the latter part of June. The growth of the crop was luxuriant after the plants were well started, bu a part of the ground was so strongly alkaline as to prevent the germination of the seed. Twenty-flve tons of beets were gathered fron acres, only about one-half of the ground planted producing a crop. The wheat and rye occupying the balance of the plowed ground made but a small showing and may be regarded as a failure The condition of the ground was materially improved iu con3equen< e of the cultivation given and perhaps one-half of the plowed lane was sufficiently free from alkali to permit the growth of a crop Observations during the year lead to the conclusion that the land con taineil a much higher per cent of alkali which is injurious to crops than was at first susjiected and that the carbonates or black alkali wa present with the sulphates or white alkali in very liberal amounts and further that surface water used in large quantities failed to pass through the soil with sufficient quickness even near the drain to accomplish the work of removing the alkali from the soil.
